case_name: State of Jammu and Kashmir v. Bakshi Ghulam Mohammad

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 1102 of 1966 appealed from judgment and order dated December 27, 1965 of Jammu and Kashmir High Court in W.P. No. 67 of 1965.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION- Civil Appeal No. 1102 of 1966. Appeal from the judgment and order dated December 27, 1965 of the Jammu and Kashmir High Court in W. P. No. 67 of 1965.

facts.text: Appeal by State of Jammu and Kashmir, G. M. Sadiq Chief Minister, D. Dhar Home Minister against Bakshi Ghulam Mohammad.

anchor.surface_text: This is an appeal by the State of Jammu and Kashmir, G. M. Sadiq, Chief Minister of that State and D. Dhar its Home Minister. The appeal is companytested by respondent No. 1, Bakshi Ghulam Mohammad.

facts.text: Accession of State of Jammu and Kashmir to India in 1947, responsible Government set up under Sheikh Mohammad Abdullah as Prime Minister.

anchor.surface_text: After the accession of the State of Jammu and Kashmir to India in 1947, a responsible Government was set up there under the Prime Ministership of Shiekh Mohammad Abdulla.

facts.text: Bakshi Ghulam Mohammad was Deputy Prime Minister from 1947 to 1953.

anchor.surface_text: It will be numbericed that Bakshi Ghulam Mohammad was the Deputy Prime Minister of the State from 1947 to 1953 and its Prime Minister from 1953 to 1963.

facts.text: In 1953 Sheikh Mohammad Abdullah dismissed, Bakshi Ghulam Mohammad became Prime Minister, G. M. Sadiq and D. P. Dhar in Cabinet.

anchor.surface_text: In 1953 Sheikh Mohammad Abdulla was dismissed from office and a new Government was formed with Bakshi Ghulam Mohammad as the Prime Minister and G. M. Sadiq and D. P. Dhar were included in the Cabinet.

facts.text: New Constitution framed for Jammu Kashmir on January 26, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: On January 26, 1957, a new Constitution was framed for Jammu Kashmir.

facts.text: Bakshi Ghulam Mohammad Prime Minister from 1953 to 1963 for total 16 years.

anchor.surface_text: So he held these offices, one after the other, for a total period of about sixteen years.

facts.text: February 1964, G. M. Sadiq becomes Prime Minister.

anchor.surface_text: In February 1964, Shamsuddin left office and a new Govern- ment was formed with G. M. Sadiq as the Prime Minister.

facts.text: Political rivalry between G. M. Sadiq and Bakshi Ghulam Mohammad started shortly after February 1964.

anchor.surface_text: It is said that shortly thereafter, political rivalry between him and Bakshi Ghulam Mohammad started.

facts.text: August 1964, notice issued fixing Legislature session in September.

anchor.surface_text: In August 1964, a numberice was issued fixing a session of the Legislature of the State in the following September.

facts.text: On September 21, 1964, no-confidence motion against G. M. Sadiq's Ministry obtained support of majority of Assembly members according to Bakshi Ghulam Mohammad.

anchor.surface_text: According to Bakshi Ghulam Mohammad, thereafter, some of the legislators wanted to bring in vote of numberconfidence against G. M.Sadiqs Ministry and by September 21, 1964 the numberconfidence motion had obtained the support of the majority of. members of the Assembly.

facts.text: September 22, 1964 at 5 a.m., Bakshi Ghulam Mohammad and supporters arrested under Defence of India Rules.

anchor.surface_text: On September 22, 1964, at 5 oclock in the morning, Bakshi Ghulam Mohammad and some of his supporters were arrested under the Defence of India Rules.

facts.text: G. M. Sadiq challenges genuineness of signatures on no-confidence notice and denies majority support.

anchor.surface_text: G. M. Sadiq challenges the genuineness of the, signatures on the numberice of the motion and also denies that it had the support of, a majority- of the Assembly-

facts.text: September 22, 1964 at 9 a.m., Legislative Assembly prorogued by Speaker under directions of Sadar-i-Riyasat.

anchor.surface_text: At 9 a.m. the Legislative Assembly which was to meet on that day,. was prorogued by the Speaker under the directions of the Sadar-i-Riyasat, the companystitutional head of the State.

facts.text: Sometime in November 1964, petition for writ of habeas corpus for release of Bakshi Ghulam Mohammad presented to High Court.

anchor.surface_text: Sometime in November 1964, a petition for a writ of habeas companypus for the release of Bakshi Ghulam Mohammad was presented to the High Court of Jammu and Kashmir.

facts.text: December 15, 1964, Bakshi Ghulam Mohammad released from arrest before habeas petition heard.

anchor.surface_text: On December 15, 1964, before the petition companyld be heard and decided, Bakshi Ghulam Mohammad was released from arrest by the State Government.

facts.text: January 30, 1965, Notification issued appointing Commission of Inquiry by N. Rajagopala Ayyangar to inquire into assets of Bakshi Ghulam Mohammad and family in Oct 1947 and Oct 1963, and if acquired by abuse of official position per second schedule.

anchor.surface_text: On January 30, 1965, a Notification was issued by the State Government appointing a Commission of Inquiry companystituted by N. Rajagopala Ayyangar to enquire into  1  the nature and extent of the assets and pecuniary resources of Bakshi Ghulam Mohammad and the members of his family and other relatives mentioned in the first Schedule to the Order, in October 1947 and in October 1963 and  ii  whether during this period...

facts.text: Commission held sittings February 1965 to August 1965, Bakshi Ghulam Mohammad participated.

anchor.surface_text: The Commission held certain sittings between February 1965 and August 1965 in which Bakshi Ghulam Mohammad took part.

facts.text: September 1, 1965, Bakshi Ghulam Mohammad filed petition in High Court under ss. 103 and 104 of JK Constitution to strike down Notification.

anchor.surface_text: On September 1, 1965, Bakshi Ghulam Mohammad moved the High Court of Jammu and Kashmir under ss. 103 and 104 of the Constitution of Jammu and Kashmir... for a writ striking down the Notification...

facts.text: High Court allowed petition, set aside Notification and quashed Commission proceedings.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court allowed the petition, set aside the Notification and quashed the proceedings of the Commission. This appeal is against the judgment of the High Court.

facts.text: Supreme Court sets aside High Court judgment.

anchor.surface_text: In our view, for these reasons, the judgment of the High Court cannot be supported. We accordingly set it aside.

facts.text: Notification issued under Jammu Kashmir Commission of Inquiry Act, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: The Notification had been issued under the Jammu Kashmir Commission of Inquiry Act, 1962.

facts.text: Political rivalry between Bakshi Ghulam Mohammad and G. M. Sadiq not disputed.

anchor.surface_text: It is number in dispute that for some time past there was political rivalry between Bakshi Ghulam Mohammad and G. M. Sadiq.

which correspond to Arts. 226 and 227 of the Indian Constitution, for a writ striking down the Notification and quashing the proceedings of the Commission taken till then and for certain other reliefs to which it is not necessary to refer.

issues.text: Whether the Notification appointing the Commission was justified under the J&K Commission of Inquiry Act, 1962, given S.37 of the J&K Constitution making Ministers collectively responsible only to the Legislative Assembly?

anchor.surface_text: This contention is based on S. 37 of the Jammu Kashmir Constitution. That section states that the Council of Ministers shall be collectively responsible to the Legislative Assembly. It is contended that this implies that in no other way is a Minister responsible for anything that he does when in office.

issues.text: Whether the matters specified in the Notification constituted a 'definite matter of public importance' under the J&K Commission of Inquiry Act, 1962?

anchor.surface_text: the Act permitted a Commission to be set up for making an inquiry into a definite matter of public importance and the matters which the Commission had been set up to inquire into were not such.

issues.text: Whether S.10 of the J&K Commission of Inquiry Act, 1962 limits inquiries into a person's conduct to incidental matters only, precluding direct inquiry into Bakshi Ghulam Mohammad's conduct?

holdings.text: The Notification was justified under s.3 of the J&K Commission of Inquiry Act, 1962; s.37 of the J&K Constitution requiring collective responsibility of Ministers to the Legislative Assembly does not bar the Government from appointing a Commission of Inquiry into a former Minister's actions.

anchor.surface_text: This contention is based on S. 37 of the Jammu Kashmir Constitution. That section states that the Council of Ministers shall be collectively responsible to the Legislative Assembly. It is contended that this implies that in no other way is a Minister responsible for anything that he does when in office.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.37 concerns only collective responsibility of current Council; Bakshi not in Council; s.3 empowers Government independently; Legislature passed Act knowing this; no British convention imported.

holdings.text: The matters specified in the Notification constitute a definite matter of public importance under the Act, even for a former office-holder and without public agitation.

anchor.surface_text: the Act permitted a Commission to be set up for making an inquiry into a definite matter of public importance and the matters which the Commission had been set up to inquire into were not such.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Specific assets in 1947/1963 and 38 instances of abuse over 16 years; past public acts remain important; misreading of Dalmia; no need for current office or agitation; intrinsic public interest in ministerial integrity.

holdings.text: s.10 of the Act applies to direct inquiries into a person's conduct, not only incidental ones; provides hearing rights including limited cross-examination.

anchor.surface_text: 10. (1) If at any stage of the inquiry the Commission considers it necessary to inquire into the conduct of any person or is of opinion that the reputation of any person is likely to be prejudicially affected by the inquiry, the Commission shall give to that person a reasonable opportunity of being heard in the inquiry and producing evidence in his defence

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.3 wide scope; s.10 triggers on necessity to inquire into conduct (direct or incidental); illogical to protect only incidental cases.

holdings.text: The Notification was not issued mala fide; political rivalry and sequence of events do not prove malice.

anchor.surface_text: The next attack on the Notification was that it had been issued mala fide. One of the learned Judges of the High Court expressly rejected this contention

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rivalry admitted but events justified (arrest for law/order amid investigations/threats; prorogation to avert trouble; release post-investigation; CID probe, reputable Commissioner, no prosecution shows good faith).

holdings.text: No violation of Article 14; singling out Bakshi for inquiry into his alleged wealth acquisition by abuse is reasonable classification with nexus to object.

anchor.surface_text: The next ground of attack on the Notification was based on Art. 14. It was said that most of the matters into which the Commission had been directed to inquire formed the subject matters of Cabinet decisions.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Bakshi unique as alleged beneficiary/abuser; not all Cabinet members implicated similarly; rational connection to inquiry purpose.

holdings.text: No violation of natural justice in Commission's proceedings; no absolute right to cross-examine all affidavit deponents or preemptive full document inspection in fact-finding inquiry.

anchor.surface_text: It was said that this was a denial of the rules of natural justice. It is not necessary to consider this question because it is admitted that since then inspection

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rules context/statute-specific; hearing given; inspection now provided; cross-exam limited per s.10 to viva voce; varies per Nagendra Nath Bora.

holdings.text: s.4(c) of the Act gives independent power to receive affidavits, not subject to CPC O.19 r.1 proviso mandating cross-examination if desired; no right to cross-examine all deponents.

anchor.surface_text: That claim is based on s. 4 (c) of the Act. The relevant part of the section is as follows-- The Commission shall have the power of a Civil Court while trying a suit under the Code of Civil Procedure

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.4(c) not exception to non-existent oral evidence rule (no O.18 r.4 analog); s.10 not superfluous; s.9 flexible procedure; practical need for efficiency with many witnesses; rules confirm.

holdings.text: The judgment of the High Court is set aside.

anchor.surface_text: In our view, for these reasons, the judgment of the High Court cannot be supported. We accordingly set it aside.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative rejection of all grounds upholding Notification and proceedings.

precedents.citation: Ram Krishan Dalmia v. Shri Justice S. R. Tendolkar 1

anchor.surface_text: Ram Krishan Dalmia v. Shri Justice S. R. Tendolkar 1  that the companyduct of an individual may assume such a dangerous proportion and may so prejudicially affect or threaten to affect the public well-being as to make such companyduct a definite matter of public importance, urgently calling for a full inquiry.

precedents.case_name: Ram Krishna Dalmia v. Shri Justice S.R. Tendolkar
precedents.cited_proposition: conduct of an individual may assume such a dangerous proportion and may so prejudicially affect or threaten to affect the public well-being as to make such conduct a definite matter of public importance, urgently calling for a full inquiry

anchor.surface_text: Dalmias case. We are clear in our mind that this is a misreading of this Courts observation. This Court, as the learned Judges themselves numbericed, was number laying down an exhaustive definition of matters of public importance. What is to be inquired into in any case are necessarily past acts and it is because they have already affected the public well-being or their effect might do so, that they became matters of public importance.

precedents.case_name: Ram Krishna Dalmia v. Shri Justice S.R. Tendolkar
precedents.cited_proposition: not laying down an exhaustive definition of matters of public importance

anchor.surface_text: Dabnias case 1  dealt with an inquiry ordered at least in part into allegations made against people in charge of a big mercantile enterprise. Allegations may very well raise questions of great public importance. Suppose it is alleged that people in a city are suffering from ill-health and that is due- to the companytaminated water supplied by the city admi- nistration.

precedents.case_name: Ram Krishna Dalmia v. Shri Justice S.R. Tendolkar
precedents.cited_proposition: dealt with an inquiry ordered at least in part into allegations made against people in charge of a big mercantile enterprise; allegations may raise questions of great public importance

precedents.citation: Meenglas Tea Estates v. Their Workmen 1

anchor.surface_text: Meenglas Tea Estates v. Their Workmen 1 , but there all that was said was that when evidence is given viva voce against a person be must have the opportunity to hear it and to put the witnesses questions in cross-examination. That is number our case. Furthermore, in Meenglas Tea Estate case 1  the Court was number dealing With a fact finding body as we are.

precedents.case_name: Meenglas Tea Estate v. Its Workmen
precedents.cited_proposition: when evidence is given viva voce against a person he must have the opportunity to hear it and to put questions in cross-examination

precedents.citation: Nagendra Nath Bora v. Commissioner of Hills Division and Appeals, Assam 1

anchor.surface_text: Nagendra Nath Bora v. Commissioner of Hills Division and Appeals, Assam 1  that the rules of natural justice vary with the varying companystitution of statutory bodies and the rules prescribed by the Act under which they function and the question whether or number any rules of natural justice had been companytravened, should be decided number under any preconceived numberions, but in the light of the statutory rules and provisions.

precedents.case_name: Nagendra Nath Bora v. Commissioner of Hills Division and Appeals, Assam
precedents.cited_proposition: the rules of natural justice vary with the varying constitution of statutory bodies and the rules prescribed by the Act under which they function and the question whether any rules of natural justice had been contravened, should be decided not under any preconceived notions, but in the light of the statutory rules and provisions

precedents.citation: Khandesh Spinning etc. Co. Ltd. v. Rashtriya Girni Kamgar Sangh 1

anchor.surface_text: Khandesh Spinning etc. Co. Ltd. v. Rashtriya Girni Kamgar Sangh 1  where this Court dealing with a somewhat similar section like s. 4 c  observed that facts might be proved by an affidavit subject to O. 19 r.  1 . The observations appear to have been obiter dicta. In any case that case was dealing with a statute different from the one before us.

precedents.case_name: Khandesh Spinning and Weaving Mills Co. Ltd. v. Rashtriya Girni Kamgar Sangh
precedents.cited_proposition: facts might be proved by an affidavit subject to O. 19 r. 1

anchor.surface_text: This contention is based on S. 37 of the Jammu Kashmir Constitution. That section states that the Council of Ministers shall be collectively responsible to the Legislative Assembly. It is contended that this implies that in no other way is a Minister responsible for anything that he does when in office.
In our view, for these reasons, the judgment of the High Court cannot be supported. We accordingly set it aside.
